review_title: Great work opportunity by helping clients.
pros: I received the proper training so I can perform my duties as needed.
cons: I could not think of any right now.

review_title: Culture is good, many things are good. But, here's what I wish I knew before.
pros:
*Primarily in-center, reduced number of miles placed on personal vehicle and facilitates stacking billable hours back to back without a commute in-between.
*Narrow hours of operation encourage a healthy work-life balance. During summer M-Th 8a-5p & Fri 8a-4p (gotta love it).
*Clinical support assistants: assist with much of the grunt work, freeing the supervisors to engage in clinical significant work and reducing burn-out.
*Work Culture is really solid.
*Leadership appears receptive to feedback.
cons:
*No sick pay, as this is baked into your PTO benefits.
*No reduction of billable expectation for the first two PTO days you use on a per-month basis. On your third day off and each day after you get 6 hours reduced on a per-moth basis. 
*Drive time does not count as your work time for salaried employees, while still required to work 8-hour days/40-hour weeks. As a result, I've lost up to an hour and a half commuting between centers or client's homes for the sole purpose of delivering my billable obligations, but had to stay later to complete my "8-hour day" as if I went on a drive for my sole enjoyment. 
*For Mid-Tiers, forced to sign a contract for BCBA supervision to forcibly stay after becoming a BCBA, there is no shortage of organizations that do not require such contracts for supervision. My understanding, they are largely unenforceable in the beautiful state of California, but it's a drag they decide to operate like this.

job_title: Board Certified Behavior Analyst (BCBA) in Emeryville, CA
pros: You’ll gain trauma bonds with peers and team.
cons: Toxic workplace, poor quality of care administered.

pros: Flexible schedule, professional development opportunities, collaborative, supportive teams
cons: Initially lower pay but able to move up pay scale, potential for lots of driving

pros: Great satisfaction working with kids on the spectrum
cons: management/leadership at the time was not the best

pros: supportive staff and learned a lot on the job, also they pay for your certification
cons: not much room for growth and schedule can be changed quickly

review_title: Depends on what you're looking for
pros: Kind coworkers, plenty of hands-on experience
cons: Inconsistent scheduling, inconsistent supervision. ABA services in general seem like an outdated method of treatment, and any conversations around the ethics of work practices with children are out of the question.

pros: they are flexible and friendly
cons: Communication lacks & management need improvement. Needs to have more regard for employees time

pros: Great pay, collaborative environment, supportive supervisors and coworkers
cons: Supervision of BT's on a case could be more varied

review_title: Great experience for teachers and future educators
pros: There are many peers willing to help you learn the process as a behavior technician. The staffs are friendly.
cons: You have to be willing to work with autistic children and their parents. The pay is definitely low for what you do.

pros: Reasonable salary, educational environment, working with children
cons: Physically and mentally exhausting, limited PTO
